title: Green cryptocurrencies and environmental sustainability — how “green” is actually achieved
keyQuestions: What makes a cryptocurrency “green” in technical terms?
How do PoS, DPoS, PoA, and proof of space/time change energy use?
What does credible carbon accounting look like for a blockchain project?
How can crypto operations align with renewables and grid stability?
What are the sustainability trade-offs (centralization, e-waste, hardware churn)?
How can users and builders spot real environmental progress versus marketing?
quickSteps: Check the consensus model and its real-world energy profile (PoS vs PoW, plus operational choices).
Look for transparent reporting: dashboards, audits, and consistent methodology for footprint estimates.
Verify renewable strategy and location choices; avoid vague claims with no evidence.
Assess hardware and governance: upgrades should not force rapid e-waste cycles.
Use a simple checklist to separate measurable reductions from slogans.

issueRouting.start: I want to understand whether a crypto project is genuinely sustainable

branches.if: The project claims to be green but shows no measurements
then: Look for public power/footprint reporting and repeatable methodology
Check for dashboards or audits that users can verify
Treat unmeasured claims as marketing until proven

branches.if: Consensus is efficient but decentralization looks weak
then: Review validator concentration and governance controls
Check whether the model relies on a small trusted set (PoA) or stake whales (PoS)
Balance sustainability with credible security and openness

branches.if: Hardware churn and e-waste risk seems high
then: Prefer designs that run on commodity hardware and minimize forced upgrades
Check upgrade cadence and compatibility commitments
Consider the full lifecycle: devices, replacements, and reuse markets

riskNotes: Low-energy consensus can still concentrate power if governance is weak.
Offsets vary in quality; transparency and verification matter more than slogans.
Storage-based models can create e-waste if incentives push rapid hardware churn.
Sustainability is operational as much as technical: where and how nodes run is part of the footprint.
